awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Genetic Architecture and Proximate Mechanisms Underlying Indirect Genetic Effects on Cooperative Antipredator Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
A central problem in modern biology is understanding how an individual's traits, whether physical features, disease or behavior, result from the combined action of genes, the physical environment and the social environment in which an individual interacts. Describing genetic influences on behavior is particularly challenging if genes in social partners interact to generate behavior. Little is known about the extent of such genetic influences, whether their effects vary across populations or the physiological mechanisms that allow the genes in one individual to influence another individual's behavior. Trinidadian guppies are an excellent model system to study these effects on behavior because guppies perform a suite of cooperative antipredator behavior that is strongly influenced by social partners and which varies greatly across populations depending on predation risk. This project uses statistical genetics to describe the relative importance of an individual's own genes and those of its social partners for generating cooperation among guppies. This project will also link variation in physiology, gene expression, and sensory anatomy to variation in cooperation across populations. Undergraduates from under-represented groups will be provided long-term comprehensive research and mentorship experiences. An active learning curriculum for evolution classes will be developed. This work will advance our scientific understanding of the genetics of complex traits, including social behavior, while preparing diverse students to be scientists, educators, and mentors.

How interacting phenotypes, such as cooperation, evolve depends on both the genetic architecture of the behavior and the structure of the social environment. This project will describe the complete genetic architecture of indirect genetic effects (IGEs) on guppy antipredator behavior, especially as it might vary with changes in social selection imposed by cooperation under differential predation risk. A quantitative genetic breeding design paired with behavioral experiments will measure the influence imposed by and responsiveness to social partners and genetic covariances between those traits for high and low predation populations. Variation in these traits will be correlated with differences in gene expression for hormone receptors and cognate hormone secretion, pheromone excretion, and somatosensory anatomy. Differences in social environments will be characterized by measuring the proportions of individuals in each population that are influential on and/or responsive to social their partners. Lastly, the combination of influential and responsive partners will be varied to measure how well different combinations cooperate, quantifying differences in social selection across populations. This work will provide some of the first experimental links between proximate mechanisms, variation in IGEs, and social selection.  Data will be archived and made publically available through Dryad Digital Repository and GenBank, as appropriate.

por.por_cntn:
Describing how genotype links to phenotype is a central focus of modern evolutionary biology and behavioral ecology. Evolutionary genetics studies seek to partition the variation in traits that results from variation in genes, the environment, and the interactions between genes and environment, termed plasticity. Plasticity in behavior results from interactions with social partners, in addition to “general” environmental cues, such as the presence or absence of a predator. For example, Trinidadian guppies may alter the degree to which they are willing to cooperate with a social partner to assess the potential risk from a large predator based on whether that partner has previously cooperated.  Cooperative antipredator behavior in Trinidadian guppies is therefore an “interacting phenotype,” resulting from a combination of an individual’s own genotype, the genotype of its social partner, the general environment, and interactions between all three of these factors. The purpose of this grant was to understand how the environment provided by social partners affects the expression and evolution of interacting phenotypes, particularly cooperative antipredator behavior by 1) describing how cooperation is inherited, 2) what specific genes and morphological traits underlie cooperative behavior, and 3) how the composition of groups influences the outcomes of cooperation. The educational goals of the grant included creating a lab manual for a major’s evolution class and active learning resources for introductory biology, evolution, and animal behavior courses. Last, the grant aimed to support a diverse science pipeline by creating long-term substantive research experiences for students from groups historically excluded from science.

 

Intellectual Merit

Using techniques from molecular genetics, quantitative genetics, and ecophysiology, we identified roles for three related physiological and sensory systems in generating cooperative interacting phenotypes: vision, the mechanosensory lateral line organ, and estrogen signaling, including both circulating and excreted 17β-estradiol, as well as gene expression for estrogen receptor and its downstream effects. Fish continuously excrete 17β-estradiol, along with other hormones, into the water. Levels of circulating 17β-estradiol can change rapidly in response to environmental stimuli, including estrogens in the environment, and circulating levels of hormones influence behavior, in part by altering the expression of many other genes. We found that altering a fish’s behavior by exposing them to endocrine disrupting compounds changes the behavior of untreated social partners with whom they interact. We found that levels of estrogen receptor expression predicted the degree to which fish could match their social partners when cooperating. When we pharmacologically manipulated estrogen receptor expression, we altered both visual acuity and expression of cooperative behavior. We also found that fish integrate visual and mechanosensory signals from the lateral line organ to coordinate cooperative interactions. Finally, we found that fish from different genetic backgrounds show significant variation in all of these traits. Thus, we have described a pathway linking estrogen physiology in one social partner with the expressed cooperative behavior in a second social partner (Figure 1).

I developed several sets of introductory and upper-level evolution and behavior active learning exercises spanning a range of topics from introductory population genetics to advanced evolutionary concepts and include both formal scientific and public science communication. Some of the curriculum helps students understand the history of white supremacy and colonialism in Evolution and Behavioral Ecology, which is consistent with the grant goals of contributing to a more diverse science pipeline and improving belonging in science. Collectively, all of these activities were adopted by all instructors who teach these courses at Stonehill College, leading to more than 4000 students interacting with these materials.

 

Broader Impacts

I utilized a rolling mentee/mentor system connecting older students to younger students and current students to lab alums. Eighty-three students participated in research associated with the grant, receiving an average of three semesters of research credit and/or one and a half summers of work for those who participated in summer research. The grant provided thirty-three fulltime paid summer research fellowships. Sixty-one percent of student researchers identify as part of a group historically excluded from participation in biology, including 24% students of color, 34% first-generation college students, 3% disabled students, and 48% women and non-binary students.  Eighty-two of these student researchers have or are on track to graduate with a science degree. Graduates have gone on to engage in diverse careers, but are overwhelmingly concentrated in STEM (39%), health (45%), and science education (6%) jobs and current graduate programs. One student from this grant has completed a PhD and four more are PhD candidates in the biological sciences. As such, the grant has contributed significantly to a diverse and flourishing STEM and education workforce.
